There is very little shade on this strenuous hike. It is not recommended in the summer heat. Make sure to bring adequate food and water supplies and proper sun protection. Visitors seeking a shorter trail can hike to Lost Horse Mine out and back instead of completing the loop.
audioDescription: The Lost Horse Mine Trailhead is a dirt trail starting from a dirt parking lot. The area is surrounded by rocky hills with scattered Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs. There is a pit toilet on the west end of the parking lot near the dirt road that provides access to the area.

title: Lost Horse Mine
listingDescription: Lost Horse Mine was one of the few successful mines from the late 1800's to early 1900's in the area that is now Joshua Tree National Park.

images.altText: Rugged mountains with scattered shrubs and rocks. In the distance stands wooden remains of a mine.
images.title: Lost Horse Mine
images.caption: Lost Horse Mine

bodyText:
Lost Horse Mine was one of the few successful mining operations of the more than 300 mines in what is now Joshua Tree National Park. The mining rights were originally purchased by Johnny Lang for $1,000. Realizing for safety that he needed more people in such a remote location, Lang brought in three partners before they were ultimately bought out in 1895 by J.D. Ryan, a wealthy rancher from Montana. From 1894 to 1931 the mine produced more than 10,000 ounces of gold and 16,000 ounces of silver (worth approximately $5 million today).

According to legend, the day shift was producing significantly more than the night shift so Ryan hired a private investigator to figure out what was happening. Upon discovering that Lang was pocketing half the ore for himself, Ryan forced Lang to decide between selling out or going to jail. Ultimately Lang sold his share and moved his prospecting to a nearby canyon.

In 1905, miners hit a fault and lost the vein of ore forever. Over the next couple of decades the mine changed hands several times and went through long periods of inactivity before ultimately becoming a part of Joshua Tree National Monument in 1936.

Today, the Lost Horse Mine can be reached on the Lost Horse Mine Loop Trail as part of a four mile out and back hike with 550 feet of elevation or as part of a longer loop for those that want a longer hike. Fences have been placed around the mine for safety, do not try to cross the fence and enter the mine as the area is unstable. Historic structures may seem safe but can easily crumble under a person's weight. Do not be fooled by appearances! Lost Horse Mine is a unique place and an important part of Joshua Tree's history. Please protect this place and report graffiti and other vandalism to JOTR_Graffiti@nps.gov.
audioDescription: Lost Horse Mine is located on the side of a rocky mountain. There is a wooden structure with metal pulleys at the mines entrance that is surrounded by a chain link fence. The area has scattered remains of walls, debries, and two water tanks above the wooden structure. Shrubs and rocks are scattered throughout the area. The whole area is surrounded by rocky mountains.

title: Lost Horse Mine Trailhead
listingDescription: The Lost Horse Mine Trailhead provides access to the Lost Horse Mine Loop Trail and the Lost Horse Mine.

images.altText: A dirt road going by rocky hills with a dirt trail leaving the road and heading over a rocky hill.
images.title: Lost Horse Mine Trailhead
images.caption: Lost Horse Mine Trailhead

bodyText:
The Lost Horse Mine trail is a 4-mile (round trip) out-and-back hike with 550 feet of elevation gain. Lost Horse Mine operated from 1893 to 1936, producing over 9,000 ounces of gold. It was one of the most successful mines in the Joshua Tree National Park area. Stay outside the fenced area to protect the mill site and mine when exploring near the mine.  

For a longer hike, continue on the Lost Horse Loop, a 6.2-mile loop hike with 1292 ft of elevation gain. There is very little shade, so it is not recommended in the summer heat. Make sure to bring adequate food and water supplies and proper sun protection.
audioDescription: The Lost Horse Mine Trailhead is a dirt trail starting from a dirt parking lot. The area is surrounded by rocky hills with scattered Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs. There is a pit toilet on the west end of the parking lot near the dirt road that provides access to the area.

title: Lost Palms Oasis
listingDescription: A desert oasis in the southeastern portion of Joshua Tree National Park.

images.altText: A group of fan palms in a rocky canyon with the canyon walls towering overhead.
images.title: Lost Palms Canyon and Oasis
images.caption: Lost Palms Canyon and Oasis

bodyText: Lost Palms Oasis is located in the southeastern portion of Joshua Tree National Park. This oasis can be reached on a 7.5 mile out and back hike from Cottonwood Spring with 500 feet of elevation gain. The trail is on a mix of rock, dirt, and sandy washes with very little shade and includes a strenuous climb on rocky terrain out of the canyon that the oasis is located in at the far end of the trail. The oasis is located in Lost Palms Canyon where a permanent water source allows fan palms and other plants to thrive, supporting a vibrant desert wildlife community.
audioDescription: Lost Palms Oasis is located at the bottom of a rocky desert canyon. The oasis contains a number of fan palms as well as small trees and shrubs. There may be some pools of water present in the canyon bottom from the oasis. The area is surrounded by rocky canyon walls. A dirt and rock path leads down into the canyon to the oasis at the bottom.

title: Lost Palms Oasis Trailhead
listingDescription: Hike to the Lost Palms Oasis

images.altText: A large stand of California Fan palms spread through a canyon of boulders.
images.title: Lost Palms Oasis

bodyText:
The Lost Palms Oasis Trail is a 7.5-mile (round trip) out-and-back hike with 500 feet of elevation gain. The trail leads through a diverse landscape of sandy washes and rocky mountainous terrain, and ends at Lost Palms Oasis, one of five fan palm oases in the park. The oasis is a refuge for a variety of birds and mammals, including the occasional bighorn sheep. Water, food, and shelter attract animals to this unique ecosystem.   

This hike is great for those looking for a longer day hike and opportunities to see wildlife.  

The trail is considered challenging because of its length and the strenuous climb out of the oasis. It has very little shade and is not recommended in the summer heat. Bring adequate food and water supplies, and wear sun protection.
audioDescription: The trailhead is a lush desert oasis surrounded by rocky hills. The oasis is filled with many types of plants including fan palms, Joshua trees, other small trees, and shrubs. The oasis is located down a short dirt path from a paved parking lot with a paved sidewalk. Next to the trailhead is a backpacking board with information on backpacking. The area around the parking lot is filled with scattered Joshua trees, short trees, and shrubs.

title: Lucky Boy Loop Trailhead

images.altText: A dirt trail going between desert shrubs past a backpacking bulletin boards towards mountains.
images.title: Pine City Backpacking Board
images.caption: Pine City Backpacking Board

bodyText:
Lucky Boy Loop is a 3.25-mile hike with 555 ft of elevation gain. This loop leads hikers through diverse scenery of desert vegetation, rock formations, vista points, and the remains of Elton Mine. Look out for wildlife including scrub jays fluttering in the Pinyon pines, lizards basking on the rocks, and cottontails hiding in the shrubs. If you’re lucky, you may even spot a desert tortoise making its way across the landscape or eating some of the springtime wildflowers. The last section of the loop is .5 mile along the dirt Desert Queen Mine Road back to the Pine City parking lot. Keep an eye out for passing vehicles. 

 

This trail is not recommended in the summer heat, due to it’s length and lack of shade. Make sure to bring adequate food and water supplies and proper sun protection.
audioDescription: Pine City Trailhead is located in an open area of desert. The trail starts from a dirt parking lot that is accessed by a dirt road. From the parking area two dirt trails head off into the surrounding area, with the Pine City Trail heading north and the Lucky Boy Vista Trail heading south. The area is filled with scattered rocks, Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs. Next to the trailhead is a backpacking board with information on backpacking and a box for backpackers to self register. There are rocky mountains in the distance.

title: Malapai Hill Viewpoint Parking Area
listingDescription: The parking area to access views of Malapai Hill.

images.altText: A sun setting behind a dark-colored hill
images.title: Malapai Hill Viewpoint
images.caption: The view of Malapai Hill near its parking area.

bodyText:
Construction by Destruction 

Unlike the incremental changes caused by weathering and erosion, some geologic process have changed Joshua Tree’s landscape in short, violent events.  

Malapai Hill 

Volcanic Origins: Standing tall above Queen Valley to the west, the hard, black basalt of Malapai Hill weathers and erodes slowly. This volcano is much younger than the surrounding monzogranite and likely formed within the past 15 million years. 

Blue Cut Fault 

Ancient Earnt Valley: Located to the south southwest, there has not been an earthquake on this fault in the last 8,000 years, but it is still active and could generate a moderate earthquake. One of many fault lines in the park, the Blue Cut Fault extends for over 50 miles (80 km) through the heart of the park. Earthquakes on this fault have resulted in over four miles of offset over the last few million years, with the north side of the fault moving west and the south side moving to the east and the uplift of the Hexie Mountains along the northern edge of Pleasant Valley.

Exploration Area  

Explore the ancient remnants of a volcano with desert views —hike to the top of Malapai Hill or around its base. Do not attempt during high temperatures. 

Glossary 

Erosion: A geological process in which natural forces such as wind or water move natural materials like rocks, dirt, and sand.  

Weathering: natural process when water, wind, heat, plants and other forces, slowly break or change the rock. 

Basalt: A dark fine-grained volcanic (i.e. igneous) rock.  

Uplift: The elevation of the Earth’s crust. Usually referring to tectonic uplift caused by slowly moving plates that cause earthquakes and changes to the earth’s surface.
audioDescription: A small, dirt pullout on the west side of the road. The view to the west reveals a dark-colored hill. To the south is a gently sloping plain towards mountains. To the north and east lie a few small rock formations. Desert vegetation surrounds the pullout.

title: Mastodon Peak Trailhead
listingDescription: Trailhead for Mastodon Peak trail in the Cottonwood area of Joshua Tree National Park.

images.altText: A hiker walks down a scree-covered trail next to tall boulders.
images.title: Mastodon Peak
images.caption: Hiker on Mastodon Peak Trail

bodyText:
Mastodon Peak is a moderate three mile loop with 375 feet of elevation gain. This hike starts from the Cottonwood Spring Oasis parking lot and starts on the Lost Palms Oasis Trail by Cottonwood Spring before splitting off to the left on the Mastodon Peak Loop. This hike provides great views of the southern portion of the park and includes an option scramble up to the top of the craggy granite peak.

This hike can be combined with the Lost Palms Oasis Trail for a longer hike.

This trail has no shade and no cell service. Always check the weather forecast before heading into the park and consider changing plans if the weather conditions are too extreme. Before hiking, tell a safety buddy where you are going and when you plan on leaving the park. Summer hikers should start this trail before 9 am and bring plenty of water.
audioDescription: The trailhead is a lush desert oasis surrounded by rocky hills. The oasis is filled with many types of plants including fan palms, Joshua trees, other small trees, and shrubs. The oasis is located down a short dirt path from a paved parking lot with a paved sidewalk. Next to the trailhead is a backpacking board with information on backpacking as well as an interpretive sign. The area around the parking lot is filled with scattered Joshua trees, short trees, and shrubs.

title: Maze Loop Trailhead
listingDescription: Trailhead for the Maze Loop Trail

images.altText: A sandy path leading down rock formations on the Maze Loop Trail.
images.title: Maze Loop

bodyText:
Hike this 5-mile loop trail with an elevation gain of 400 ft. and be led through a maze of Joshua Tree National Park’s famous granite rock formations. Start the hike in a sandy wash before meandering through boulder piles and Joshua tree woodlands. Look above and you might find large ravens or a hawk flying overhead. Watch below and there may be cottontail rabbits, lizards, or the occasional desert tortoise traveling across the landscape. 

Hikers can connect to other trails via Maze Loop including North View Trail and Big Pines Trail. Expect steep sections and pay close attention to trail markers. Some sections of the trail may be hard to identify between washes and social trails. Use the app’s integrated map to help you navigate.  
 

This trail is not recommended in the summer heat, due to it’s length and lack of shade. Make sure to bring adequate food and water supplies and proper sun protection.
audioDescription: A small dirt parking area sits off Park Boulevard with dirt paths leading away from the lot. The landscape has large boulder formations and is scattered with Joshua trees and desert shrubs.

title: Minerva Hoyt (Minerva Hoyt Trail)
listingDescription: Learn about Minerva Hoyt at this stop on the audio tour.

images.altText: A trail begins through a desert landscape with a sign that reads "No Pets on Trails" in large text.
images.title: Minerva Hoyt Trailhead

bodyText:
The Minerva Hoyt Trail is an out-and-back hike to the Hidden Valley picnic area. It is 3 miles roundtrip with 100 feet of elevation gain. From the parking lot, the trail follows an old road before it takes a sharp right towards Hidden Valley. The hike goes through a valley of Joshua trees with excellent views of unique rock formations and mountains in the distance. It can be combined with the 1-mile Hidden Valley Nature Trail to create a 4-mile “lollipop” loop.  

The trail is named after Minerva Hoyt, the founding force behind Joshua Tree National Park. She lobbied congress and President FDR to preserve the area. Her efforts helped the park become designated as a National Monument in 1936. It later became a National Park in 1994.

After abundant winter rains, this trail offers a vibrant springtime display of wildflowers. For more information on wildflowers, visit our Wildflower Viewing Page.

title: Minerva Hoyt Trailhead
listingDescription: Trailhead for the Minerva Hoyt Trail

images.altText: A trail begins through a desert landscape with a sign that reads "No Pets on Trails" in large text.
images.title: Minerva Hoyt Trailhead

bodyText:
The Minerva Hoyt Trail is an out-and-back hike to the Hidden Valley picnic area. It is 3 miles roundtrip with 100 feet of elevation gain. From the parking lot, the trail follows an old road before it takes a sharp right towards Hidden Valley. The hike goes through a valley of Joshua trees with excellent views of unique rock formations and mountains in the distance. It can be combined with the 1-mile Hidden Valley Nature Trail to create a 4-mile “lollipop” loop.  

The trail is named after Minerva Hoyt, the founding force behind Joshua Tree National Park. She lobbied congress and President FDR to preserve the area. Her efforts helped the park become designated as a National Monument in 1936. It later became a National Park in 1994.

After abundant winter rains, this trail offers a vibrant springtime display of wildflowers. For more information on wildflowers, visit our Wildflower Viewing Page.
audioDescription: The Minverva Hoyt Trailhead is located in a large open and flat area along Park Boulevard. The parking area is a paved parking lot with two entrances to the main road. In the northwest corner is a trailhead with a sign reading Minverva Hoyt Trailhead. The area has scattered Joshua trees, small trees and shrubs. In the distance are rocky mountains.

title: Mining History (Juniper Flats)
listingDescription: Hike the Juniper Flats Backcountry Region

images.altText: A trailhead sign reads" Juniper Flats" in a landscape of scattered Joshua trees and desert shrubs.
images.title: Juniper Flats Backpacking Board

bodyText:
The Juniper Flats Zone features open valleys, mountainous terrain, and panoramic views. It offers higher, cooler elevations ranging from ~4,400 to nearly 5,600 feet. During the colder months, freezing temperatures are common.

The Juniper Flats Backcountry Trailhead is the starting point for the following hikes:

  • Big Trees (6 miles)

  • Stubbe Springs (12 miles)


Visitors can also access the California Riding and Hiking Trail at this trailhead.

Find detailed information on each trail in the Hiking section on the app's homepage.
audioDescription: There is a dirt parking lot behind a fence post. A roofed backcountry trailhead reads "Juniper Flats" and provides information about the surrounding area. The dirt path leads away from the trailhead into a landscape with desert shrubs, grasses, and many Joshua trees. There are rocky mountains in the distance.

title: Musical Connection (Cap Rock)
listingDescription: Learn about the musical connections to Joshua Tree National Park at the Cap Rock stop on the audio tour.

images.altText: A large rock formation with Joshua trees in the foreground under clouds lit pink by the sunset.
images.title: Cap Rock at Sunset
images.caption: Cap Rock at sunset.

bodyText: Cap Rock is a popular rock formation in the central part of Joshua Tree National Park. Located near the north end of Keys View Road near Park Boulevard, Cap Rock is an easy to reach location. In addition to the unique rock formation, Cap Rock offers a picnic area with grills as well as the Cap Rock Nature Trail for a short walk through nearby rock formations with interpretive signs along the way to learn about the area. The area around Cap Rock and the nature trail are flat dirt and gravel surfaces.
audioDescription: Cap Rock is a popular rock formation in the central part of Joshua Tree National Park. Located near the north end of Keys View Road near Park Boulevard, Cap Rock is an easy to reach location. In addition to the unique rock formation, Cap Rock offers a picnic area with grills as well as the Cap Rock Nature Trail for a short walk through nearby rock formations with interpretive signs along the way to learn about the area. The area around Cap Rock and the nature trail are flat dirt and gravel surfaces.

title: Nolinas - Not Yuccas

images.altText: A green long leafed plant sits next to a dirt path surrounded by other desert shrubs.
images.title: Perry's Nolinas

bodyText: Parry’s nolina (Nolina parryi) is a hardy desert plant with long, thin, flexible leaves that make it easy to tell apart from Joshua trees or yuccas. In the spring, nolinas can grow a very tall flower stalk-- up to 12 feet tall! The flowers are cream colored and appear like a cone of popcorn on top of the stalk. Nolinas are slow growing plants that can live to be hundreds- possibly even over 1,000 years old.
audioDescription: This stop is located along a dirt trail on the side of a desert mountain. The mountain slopes down to the north revealing a wide view with mountains in the distance. The area is filled with scatter Joshua trees, small trees, nolinas, and shrubs.

title: North Entrance Station
listingDescription: The North Entrance Fee Station is near the town of Twentynine Palms.

images.altText: Flowers and a small building
images.title: The North Entrance Station
images.caption: The North Entrance Fee Station

bodyText:
The North Entrance Station is a small fee booth located where Utah Trail becomes Park Boulevard. Visitors can pay their entrance fees or buy a park pass here as they go into the park. Park rangers may also collect fees or check passes here as visitors drive or bike out of the park.

If there is no ranger present or the fee booth is closed, visitors can continue to drive into the park without showing their pass or paying the entrance fee unless a special circumstance closes the park roads, like a weather closure.
audioDescription: There is a small building in the middle of Park Boulevard between incoming and outgoing traffic. There is a stop sign to indicate where drivers should stop to pay their entrance fees or show their pass. There is a flagpole in front of the building.

title: North View Trailhead
listingDescription: Trailhead for the North View Trail

images.altText: A rocky mountainous landscape with shadows cast from mountains out of view.
images.title: North View Trail

bodyText:
The North View Trail is a 5.6 mile (round trip) out-and-back hike with 836 ft. of elevation gain. It can be made into a loop hike by connecting with the Maze Loop Trail or Window Loop Trail.  

North View Trail offers sweeping valley views of Joshua Tree National Park and the Morongo Basin. You’ll trek through valleys between towering boulder, sandy washes, rocky ridges and landscapes scattered with Joshua trees and native desert cacti. There are two short spur trails that lead to the viewpoints of Copper Mountain and Western Hills. 

Expect steep sections and pay close attention to trail markers. Use the app’s integrated map to help you navigate. This trail is not recommended in the summer heat, due to it’s length and lack of shade. Make sure to bring adequate food and water supplies and proper sun protection.
audioDescription: A small dirt parking lot sits right off the main road with dirt paths leading away from it. Large boulders and Joshua trees scatter the landscape. Rocky mountains stand tall in the distance.

title: Oaks and Pines

images.altText: A collection of oak and pinyon pines surrounded by other desert shrubs.
images.title: Oaks and Pines

bodyText: While common in the Black Rock Canyon area, mature stands of pine and oak trees like these are relatively rare in Joshua Tree National Park. These species prefer a slightly cooler climate and are therefore confined to the higher elevations of the Little San Bernardino Mountains. Pinyon pine trees (Pinus pinaceae) are of particular concern to scientists as changing climate threatens the existence of this species in its current range.
audioDescription: This stop is located along a dirt path with small ridges on either side. The area contains scattered Joshua trees, small trees and shrubs. The trail inclines to the southeast as the ridges get closer together while the area opens up to the northwest revealing mountains in the distance.

title: Oasis of Mara
listingDescription: A desert oasis located a short walk from the Oasis Visitor Center in the town of Twentynine Palms.

images.altText: A clump of fan palm trees in a desert valley under a stormy sky and rainbow.
images.title: Oasis of Mara
images.caption: Oasis of Mara under a rainbow

bodyText:
The Oasis of Mara is the easiest to reach oasis in Joshua Tree National Park. Located near the Joshua Tree National Park headquarters in the town of Twentynine Palms, this oasis is reached by a short and level paved path. The water from this oasis supports a vibrant plant and wildlife community, including a cluster of California fan palms, making this a good location for viewing desert plant and wildlife. 

The Oasis of Mara has also long supported human life in the area. Named "Mara", meaning "the place of little springs and much grass" by the Serrano, this oasis is believed to be their first home in this world. According to their traditions, the fan palms at this oasis were first planted for every boy born in the village. The water of this oasis was able to support a village to live in the desert by providing the necessary water for the plants needed for food and materials to make items such as baskets, sandals, and homes.
audioDescription: The Oasis of Mara is in a broad desert valley. The oasis contains a number of fan palm trees as well as other scattered small trees and shrubs. The oasis is reached by a paved path. Around the main group of fan palms there is a wooden split rail fence to protect the oasis. Near the oasis is a bench and sign with information on the oasis. Rocky mountains rise up along the horizon to the south.

title: Oasis of Mara Trailhead

images.altText: A colorful sunset over a paved path that goes between shrubs towards desert palms in the distance.
images.title: Sunset at Oasis of Mara
images.caption: Sunset at Oasis of Mara

bodyText:
The Oasis of Mara Trail is a peaceful, 0.5-mile paved trail that winds around a fan palm oasis. The trail is great for visitors looking for an easy stroll and offers a fantastic opportunity for birdwatching. Watch for common birds such as cactus wren, phainopepla, and Gambel's quail. Along the trail are educational signs about Native American history, knowledge, and modern connection to the area.  

Among the five fan palm oases in Joshua Tree National Park, the Oasis of Mara is one of the easiest to visit and see. The trailhead is located at park headquarters in Twentynine Palms, CA. The trail is wheelchair accessible and stroller friendly. 

To learn more about the Oasis of Mara, click here.
audioDescription: The Oasis of Mara Nature Trail starts from a covered patio paved with tiles next to the white one story visitor center. Heading west, a paved trail heads out into a desert landscape between desert palms, small trees, and shrubs. Nearby on the patio area there are interpretive signs, picnic tables, and trash cans.

title: Ocotillo (Ocotillo Patch)
listingDescription: Scenic view along Pinto Basin Road.

images.altText: A valley with flowering yellow shrubs and taller ocotillos with red flowers in front of mountains.
images.title: Ocotillo Patch
images.caption: Ocotillo Patch

bodyText: Ocotillo Patch is a scenic pull off along Pinto Basin Road located between two mountain ranges in an alluvial fan, a place where sediments spread out from a narrow area, often carried by water. This area gets more moisture from runoff to support more plants, including the high number of ocotillo that are located here. This pull off includes an interpretive display as well as sweeping panoromic views of the area.
audioDescription: Ocotillo Patch is located in a wide desert valley surrounded by mountains. There is a dirt pull off for parking with 360 degree views of the desert. The area is filled with small trees and shrubs.

title: Ocotillo Patch
listingDescription: Scenic view along Pinto Basin Road.

images.altText: A valley with flowering yellow shrubs and taller ocotillos with red flowers in front of mountains.
images.title: Ocotillo Patch
images.caption: Ocotillo Patch

bodyText: Ocotillo Patch is a scenic pull off along Pinto Basin Road located between two mountain ranges in an alluvial fan, a place where sediments spread out from a narrow area, often carried by water. This area gets more moisture from runoff to support more plants, including the high number of ocotillo that are located here. This pull off includes an interpretive display as well as sweeping panoromic views of the area.
audioDescription: Ocotillo Patch is located in a wide desert valley surrounded by mountains. There is a dirt pull off for parking with 360 degree views of the desert. The area is filled with small trees and shrubs.

title: Orientation (Cottonwood Visitor Center)
listingDescription: Located on Pinto Basin Road, approximately 7 miles north of Interstate 10 (exit 168), the Cottonwood Visitor Center is a convenient stop for those entering and exiting the park from the south.

images.altText: A road leads to a tan building sits in an open desert landscape
images.title: Cottonwood Visitor Center
images.caption: Cottonwood Visitor Center

bodyText: Located on Pinto Basin Road, approximately 7 miles north of Interstate 10 (exit 168), the Cottonwood Visitor Center is a convenient stop for those entering and exiting the park from the south. It has educational exhibits, a bookstore, visitor resources, and restroom facilities. You can grab a park map, buy an entrance pass, fill up your water bottle, and chat with a park ranger to get all your questions answered.
audioDescription: The Cottonwood Visitor Center sits on a high desert plateau in the transition zone between the Mojave and Colorado deserts. To the northeast, Eagle Mountain stands lofty as a rugged backdrop. Weather can be extreme. Summers are blistering, with bright sunny weather and temperatures exceeding 100 degrees daily. Winters are cool to cold, with strong winds and sub-freezing nights. Snow is possible. The occasional rainstorm poses the threat of flash flooding. There is abundant flora and fauna nearby. Desert wilderness surrounds the visitor center. Around the building we find short desert plants. There are cacti and various flora with thorns and sharp points. Cat’s-claw acacia and many of the shrubs can be unforgiving if brushed up against. There are also plants native to the Mojave, such as yucca, juniper, and sage. In spring, red berries appear on the purple bush. Prince’s Plume are adorned with yellow flowers. The ironwood trees near the Bajada Nature Trail sprout pink and purple flowers. After a rain, the Ocotillo grow red flowers and green leaves. The Prince's Plume, ironwood trees, and Ocotillo are native to the Colorado desert. Gambel’s Quail call out throughout the day, often scurrying around the parking lot. Mule deer, coyotes, and even bighorn sheep frequent the nearby landscape. Throughout the day ravens and turkey vultures soar overheard. Black-tailed jackrabbits nervously hop along, as a red-tail hawk eyes it’s next prey from the sky. In the warmer months, rattlesnakes and desert tortoise roam the nearby sandy trails. There are three one-story buildings that comprise the visitor center facilities: The visitor center, a restroom, and a staff office. From the parking area, the visitor center is located to the left. The restroom is situated to the right of the visitor center and 30 feet across from the parking lot. The men’s restroom is located on the left side of this building, and the women’s restroom is located on the right side. There are picnic tables and bulletin boards between the restrooms and the office to the right. The visitor center also serves as a gift shop and fee-entrance station. The door is located on the south side of the building. As you enter, there is a brochure table 6 feet from the inside of the door. On the right side of the building you will see interpretive panels with information about the geology, history, and geography of Joshua Tree National Park. On the walls on the south and east side of the building are panels with quotes about the park. This side also has displays with merchandise sold by the Joshua Tree National Park Association. The front counter is 25 feet from the door where you can buy park passes and merchandise. A window on the west side of the building that has been modified to receive payments for entrance fees, directly to the left of the front counter. Plexiglass hangs around the front counter for the protection of staff and visitors. The building has standard lighting and when the blinds are up, the outside sun provides ample illumination. To the right of the front counter there are more displays for merchandise. On the east wall, there is a window with a majestic view of Eagle Mountain, Mastodon Peak, and the surrounding desert. South of this window there is a bookcase with various publications on Joshua Tree National Park. In the center of the visitor center there is a life-sized mold of a desert tortoise enclosed in glass. On the west side, to the left of the brochure table, there is a window. Next to this window there is a fold-out sign that says “Encuentra Tu Parque” (“Find your Park” in Spanish). There are more store displays as you make your way closer to the front counter. There is a small, slightly shaded courtyard in-between the visitor center and the offices. There are creosote bush and beavertail cactus in the middle. A small bench is located about 10 feet to the north of the offices. There is also a bulletin with park information, maps, and trail guides. All facilities are accessible through paved and level walkways. Outside of the visitor center, there are sidewalks between the parking lot and the buildings. The parking lot has 2 handicapped spaces, with accessible ramps and paved paths to the visitor center, restroom, and office. The office is restricted to park staff and those with authorization to enter. To the right of this building is a flagpole and a sign showing air quality and fire danger. There is also a sign that displays fees to enter the park. There is a short tenth of a mile dirt nature trail that is immediately east of the visitor center. The trail is a loop that starts a few feet from the paved path that leads to the main entrance. It ends on the east side of the parking lot. There are signs along the way identifying various plants and shrubs that can be found in the area. Park rangers here every day to answer questions and provide guidance into Joshua Tree National Park.

title: Orientation (JTVC)
listingDescription: The Joshua Tree Visitor Center is located in Joshua Tree, California

images.altText: A gray building behind a flag pole and vegetation. There is a sign for "Joshua Tree National Park"
images.title: Joshua Tree Visitor Center
images.caption: Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center

bodyText: Located in downtown Joshua Tree just five miles from the West Entrance, the Joshua Tree Visitor Center offers educational exhibits, a bookstore, and visitor resources. Grab a park map, buy an entrance pass, and chat with a park ranger to get all your questions answered before heading into the park!
audioDescription: Joshua Tree Visitor Center is located outside the park in the village of Joshua Tree, population 8,000. It is five miles north of the West Entrance on Park Boulevard close to where Park Boulevard and Highway 62 intersect. From the intersection, heading south on Park Boulevard, the visitor center is on the right. The gravel parking lot, just south of the visitor center, can comfortably fit 40 cars. There is a curved cinder block wall that divides the parking lot from the visitor center. From the parking lot, there is a cement sidewalk leading a short distance through a modest cactus garden and ends at a small cement courtyard in front of the visitor center on the east side of the building. In the garden stands a flagpole and a rusted metal sculpture. The exterior of the single-story visitor center has walls that resemble corrugated metal. From the courtyard, another short cement sidewalk leads through a large wooden gate into an outdoor patio between the cinder block wall and the south side of the building. The patio is enclosed on its south end by the previously mentioned cinder block wall. Inside the patio, the ground is dirt and slopes down from the cinder block wall towards the double glass doors that lead into the visitor center. Two tables are on the patio near the doors where rangers can help visitors with information. Once entering the building, there is a one-room exhibit area with panels depicting geology, ecology, and history of Joshua Tree National Park. There is a life-sized replica of a Joshua tree accompanied with panels about the Joshua tree. There is a guitar and a U2 record album on display that represents the creative aspects of Joshua Tree National Park. There is a television that plays a 2-minute video about the park’s geology. The exhibit opens into the one-room bookstore. On display are souvenirs—stickers, patches, t-shirts, hats, stuffed animals, mugs, postcards, and books. On the side of the bookstore closest to the exhibit is a counter with three cash registers. Opposite the counter, on the north side, are two doors that open directly into the men’s and women’s bathrooms. Exit through the bookstore's double glass doors back to the courtyard on the east side of the visitor center. The northernmost section of the building, with a single glass door that opens out into the courtyard, is a cafe.

title: Orientation (Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center)
listingDescription: Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center in Twentynine Palms, California

images.altText: A large brown and black building with an NPS arrowhead. A flagpole stands next to the parking lot.
images.title: Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center
images.caption: Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center

bodyText: The Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center is located in downtown Twentynine Palms and features educational exhibits, a bookstore and giftshop, and visitor information.
audioDescription: The Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center is located south of highway 62, by about half a block on Freedom Way. The building is surrounded by parking spaces and walkways on all sides. The visitor center is in the middle of the town of Twentynine Palms. There are other buildings in sight as well as sparse desert vegetation. To the south the mountains in the north boundary of Joshua Tree National Park can be seen. The visitor center itself is a dark tan, single-story building. There is a flag pole and shade structure near the front of the building facing highway 62. The parking spaces on the northside of the building are the closest to the front door and there are a few handicap parking spaces. There is a sidewalk surrounding the building.

title: Oyster Bar
listingDescription: A popular rock formation near Ryan Mountain with scenic views.

images.altText: A paved parking lot entrance surrounded by Joshua trees and shrubs with mountains in the distance.
images.title: Oyster Bar
images.caption: Oyster Bar

bodyText: Oyster Bar is a popular rock formation on the south side of Park Boulevard between Ryan Campground and Ryan Mountain. The parking area offers scenic views of the surrounding desert and mountains as well as access to climbing routes. If you would like to explore the rock formations by foot please use existing climber access routes to minimize your impact.
audioDescription: Oyster Bar is located in a wide desert valley on the south side of Park Boulevard. There is a paved loop parking area with an interpretive sign on the area. The area is filled with scattered Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs. Oyster Bar is a large rock formation located to the east on the side of Ryan Mountain. Rocky mountains rise up over the valley floor in the distance in every direction.

title: Paac Kü̱vü̱hü̱’k

images.altText: A trail sign next to a small, dirt trail, surrounded by rocks.
images.title: Access Trail at Paac Kü̱vü̱hü̱’k
images.caption: Trail and scenery at Paac Kü̱vü̱hü̱’k, pronounced paach kurv-er-hurk.

bodyText:
Ever-changing Landscape 

This area wasn’t always a desert. As recent at 12,000 years ago, lush green vegetation covered the valleys and mountain slopes around you. Streams once fed a seasonal lake that is now the dry playa you just drove across. 

Changing Climate 

Pleistocene Epoch: Until 12,000 years ago, the climate in this region was much cooler and wetter. Thick soils anchored by lush vegetation covered rolling hills and slopes and water flowed through year-round streams. 

Present Day: At the end of the Pleistocene, the climate dried out and warmed up. The vegetation that was adapted to a wetter climate died, leaving behind bare slopes that are more vulnerable to erosion. Valley floors filled with sediment, creating the flat plains you see today. These plains are preserved because there isn't enough running water to erode them away. 

Changing Landscape 

Look for the following features to see evidence of an ever-changing landscape.  

Bajada: Find bajadas where alluvial fans merge to form a vast sediment slope at the mouth of canyons. 

Pediment: These sloping bedrock surfaces covered by gravel can be seen along the edges of mountains.  

Dry Wash: Washes transport sediment downhill. The smallest, lightest particles are carried farthest. Desert washes fill with rushing water after rain and monsoons. The washes in Joshua Tree spend most of the year dry.  

Playa: Streams carried sediment into a now dry lake. Clay and silt deposits are hundreds of feet deep here. 

Exploration Area 

Explore the desert surrounding you on foot. Notice the small details in the plants. Look for signs of animals. Take plenty of water with you. 

Glossary 

Alluvial fans: Alluvial comes from a Latin word, alluere meaning “to wash against”. Alluvial fans generally form where mountains meet the plains. A fast-running stream moving down a steep canyon can carry more sand, rocks, and pebbles, but when the water reaches the flat plains, it flows more slowly and can't carry the larger rocks and sand anymore. (Picture how fine silt settles out of a still lake, whereas a rushing river can push along sand, pebbles, and even large rocks.) These sediments accumulate in a fan shape at the mouth of canyons or washes. 

Bajada: A bajada is where many alluvial fans meet and converge.  

Pediment: A relatively flat or slightly concave surface of bedrock.
audioDescription: A medium sized dirt parking area on the east side of the road. The area is surrounded by uniquely-shaped rock formations and desert vegetation. A valley and mountains can be seen in the distance to the south.

title: Palm Oasis (Cottonwood Spring)
listingDescription: Learn about the Palm Oases at this stop on the audio tour. A lush desert oasis that also provides access to the Mastodon Peak Loop and Lost Palms Oasis Trail.

images.altText: A lush desert oasis filled with desert palms, short trees, and shrubs in front of a rocky hill.
images.title: Cottonwood Spring Oasis
images.caption: Cottonwood Spring

bodyText: Cottonwood Spring is a lush desert oasis located in the southern portion of the Joshua Tree National Park near the Cottonwood Visitor Center off Cottonwood Spring Road. The spring is a short walk down a dirt path from the parking area, providing an opportunity to see a wide range of plant and wildlife. This trailhead also provides access to longer hikes on the Mastodon Peak Loop and Lost Palms Oasis Trail. The Cottonwood Spring Wilderness Backpacking Board is located at the trailhead for backpackers to self register for overnight backpacking trips in the area.
audioDescription: Cottonwood Spring is a lush desert oasis surrounded by rocky hills. The oasis is filled with many types of plants including fan palms, Joshua trees, other small trees, and shrubs. The oasis is located down a short dirt path from a paved parking lot with a paved sidewalk. Next to the trailhead is a backpacking board with information on backpacking as well as a box for self registration as well as an interpretive sign. The area around the parking lot is filled with scattered Joshua trees, short trees, and shrubs.

title: Panorama Loop Trailhead
listingDescription: Hike the Panorama Loop for a challenging yet rewarding hike with grand views of the surrounding mountains.

images.altText: A large Joshua tree in the middle of a trail through a desert landscape.
images.title: Joshua tree on Panorama Loop

bodyText:
Hike up a sandy wash, then follow the ridgeline of the Little San Bernardino Mountains. Enjoy scenic views, dense Joshua tree forest, and pinyon-juniper woodland. This trail is 6.6 miles and has over a 1,000 feet of elevation gain. Warren Peak can be reached from a spur-trail off of the Panorama Loop. Bring a good map when hiking in the Black Rock area because there are many trails that crisscross and intersect. 

There are a few parking areas around the Black Rock Campground and Nature Center for hikers. Parking in the campground area can fill up on busy days. Hikers cannot park in a campsite unless they have reserved that campsite. To find the trailhead, hike south from the Black Rock Nature Center, in the uphill direction. At the end of the campground, find the trail sign for panorama loop and start up the washy trail. 

This trail has limited shade and unreliable cell service. Always check the weather forecast before heading into the park and consider changing plans if the weather conditions are too extreme. Hikers should always tell a safety buddy where they are going and when they plan on leaving the park.
audioDescription: The Panorama Loop Trail starts at the Black Rock Canyon Backpacking Board. A trailhead sign with a map and photo reads "Black Rock Canyon" and stands next to a dirt path leading away from the sign. Joshua trees, small trees, and other desert plants fill the landscape. There are hills nearby the trail and larger mountains in the distance.

title: Park Overview (Joshua Tree Sign)
listingDescription: The Joshua Tree National Park entrance sign at the south end of th park.

images.altText: A brick sign reads "Entering Joshua Tree National Park" in front of a desert landscape.
images.title: Joshua Tree Entrance Sign (South)

bodyText: As you approach the park from the south, this welcome sign marks the park boundary. Take a moment to admire the Colorado Desert and the surrounding mountains. A short drive north from the sign is the Bajada Nature Trail. Continuing north, you'll come across the Cottonwood Visitor Center, campground, and other amenities.
audioDescription: A road made of pavement runs from north to south and connects the park to the interstate. Both the east and west sides of Cottonwood Spring Road have a paved pullout located on them. The landscape along the road is an open desert, which meets the edge of rocky mountains. The landscape features shrubs, Mojave Yuccas, Ocotillos, and small trees. During the spring season, wildflowers may be visible across the landscape. At the northern edge of the eastern pullout is a beige brick wall with a brown arrowhead that reads “National Park Service” and “Department of the Interior." On this sign is a large green tree, white mountain shape, and green bison painted at the bottom. To the left of the arrowhead is a large wooden sign with white paint that reads “Entering Joshua Tree National Park, United States Department of the Interior, National Park Service.”

title: Park Overview (North Entrance)
listingDescription: The North Entrance Fee Station is near the town of Twentynine Palms.

images.altText: A vehicle passes a small building with a flag pole on top. A town and mountains in the distance.
images.title: The North Entrance Station
images.caption: The North Entrance Fee Station

bodyText:
The North Entrance Station is a small fee booth located where Utah Trail becomes Park Boulevard. Visitors can pay their entrance fees or buy a park pass here as they go into the park. Park rangers may also collect fees or check passes here as visitors drive or bike out of the park.

If there is no ranger present or the fee booth is closed, visitors can continue to drive into the park without showing their pass or paying the entrance fee unless a special circumstance closes the park roads, like a weather closure.
audioDescription: There is a small building in the middle of Park Boulevard between incoming and outgoing traffic. There is a stop sign to indicate where drivers should stop to pay their entrance fees or show their pass. There is a flagpole in front of the building.

title: Peak Experience

images.altText: A high vantage view of brown hills scattered with trees and desert shrubs.
images.title: Peak Experience

bodyText: The peak of the High View Nature Trail is 4,445 feet above sea level. To the northeast lies the community of Yucca Valley, and on clear days it is easy to see the distant expanse of the Marine Corps Air Ground Combat Center, over 40 miles away. The peak of Mount San Gorgonio, to the west, is over 50 miles away. These stunning views are thanks partially to the high vantage point and lack of obstacles, and also because low humidity in desert air makes for easier long-range sightseeing.
audioDescription: This stop is along a dirt path at the top of of a rise with wide views to the north and east of the valleys below and mountains in the distance. To the south and west a ridge rises up much closer. The area is filled with scattered Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs.

title: Pine City Trailhead
listingDescription: Trailhead for Pine City and Lucky Boy Vista.

images.altText: A dirt trail going between desert shrubs past a backpacking bulletin boards towards mountains.
images.title: Pine City Backpacking Board
images.caption: Pine City Backpacking Board

bodyText: Pine City Trailhead is located in the central portion of the park at the east end of Queen Valley Road. This trailhead provides access to the Pine City Trail and the Lucky Boy Vista Trail. The Pine City Trail is a four mile out and back mostly sand and level trail with occasional steep sections that makes its way through a dense stand of junipers and pinyon. Both of these trails can be combined with other trails for longer hikes. This trailhead also has the Pine City Wilderness Backpacking Board with backpacking information and self registration for backpackers.
audioDescription: Pine City Trailhead is located in an open area of desert. The trail starts from a dirt parking lot that is accessed by a dirt road. From the parking area two dirt trails head off into the surrounding area, with the Pine City Trail heading north and the Lucky Boy Vista Trail heading south. The area is filled with scattered rocks, Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs. Next to the trailhead is a backpacking board with information on backpacking and a box for backpackers to self register. There are rocky mountains in the distance.

title: Prehistoric Animals (Pinto Basin Pullout)
listingDescription: A pullout along Pinto Basin Road.

images.altText: A large open desert landscape with mountains in the distance.
images.title: Pinto Basin Pullout

bodyText:
Welcome to the Pinto Basin. This breathtaking landscape was once characterized by lush lakes, swamps, and verdant grasslands. Although it's drier now, it remains a thriving habitat for rare desert wildlife. Wildlife found here include sidewinder rattlesnake, the jackrabbit, and Mojave fringe-toed lizard.

For those interested in stargazing, the Pinto Basin is an ideal place in Joshua Tree. The Pinto Basin offers a remote location and exceptionally dark skies. If stargazing, stay awake and alert within 20 feet (6 meters) of your vehicle.
audioDescription: The paved pullout is on the east side of Pinto Basin Road. There are marked parking spots parallel to the main paved road. The surrounding landscape is a large basin filled with sand, compact dirt, and shrubs. In the distance there are rock piles and mountains.

title: Quail Springs Picnic Area
listingDescription: Quail Springs Picnic area provides picnic tables, grills, pit toilets, and trail access.

images.altText: Two picnic tables and a grill in front of a large rock formation with scattered shrubs.
images.title: Quail Springs Picnic Area
images.caption: Quail Springs Picnic Area

bodyText: Quail Springs Picnic Area is the first picnic area along Park Boulevard when entering from the west entrance. Picnic tables and grills are nestled among Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs, next to large rock formations. The area also contains pit toilets and has trailheads for the Quail Springs Historic Trail and Ryan Johnnie Connector Trail as well as quick access to the Boy Scout Trail.
audioDescription: Quail Springs Picnic Area is located near Park Boulevard in a large open area. There are a number of picnic tables and grills nestled among Joshua Trees, small trees, and shrubs, right next to some large rock formations. The area is flat with large open dirt areas. Next to the paved parking area there are two pit toilets. Large, rocky mountains are on either side of the valley.

title: Rare Tree (Live Oak Picnic Area)
listingDescription: Learn about the Rare Tree at the Live Oak Picnic Area

images.altText: A picnic table and grill in front of a large rock formation.
images.title: Live Oak Picnic Area
images.caption: Live Oak Picnic Area

bodyText: Live Oak Picnic Area is nestled among rock formations along Park Boulevard about two miles west of its intersection with Pinto Basin Road. This picnic area provides a day use area with picnic tables and grills for people that want to enjoy a meal in the park.
audioDescription: Live Oak Picnic Area is located in a wide desert valley on the south side of Park Boulevard. A dirt road leads around the picnic area where picnic tables and grills are scattered around large rock formations. In the middle of the picnic area there is a pit toilet and trash cans. The area is filled with scattered Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs. In the distance there are rocky mountains on the horizon.

title: Rock Climbing (Intersection Rock)
listingDescription: Learn about rock climbing at Intersection Rock

images.altText: A large boulder sits behind a parking area with two vehicles. There are Joshua trees to the left.
images.title: Intersection Rock

bodyText:
Intersection Rock is a large rock formation located near Hidden Valley Campground. It is the most climbed rock in the park, with over 40 climbing routes, and a great place to watch rock climbers in action. 

There is an emergency phone attached to the bathroom in the Intersection Rock parking area next to Hidden Valley Campground.
audioDescription: A large rock formation with many cracks and flakes on the southwest edge of a paved parking lot. Surrounding this area are many other large rock boulders scattered throughout the landscape.

title: Ryan Mountain Trailhead
listingDescription: Hiking access to Ryan Mountain.

images.altText: A hiker next to a sign for Ryan Mountain by a dirt and rock trail heading towards a mountain.
images.title: Hiker at Ryan Mountain Trailhead
images.caption: A hiker at Ryan Mountain Trailhead

bodyText:
Ryan Mountain is a 3-mile (round trip) out-and-back hike with 1,050 feet of elevation gain. The summit rewards hikers with one of the best 360-degree views of any trail in the park. From the summit, you can see the Wonderland of Rocks, the Sheephole Wilderness, Mount San Jacinto towering over 10,000 feet above Palm Springs, and Mount San Gorgonio, the tallest peak in Southern California. If you are on the top on a clear day, you can even see all the way to Mexico! 

This trail also features the oldest rock type in the park – Pinto Gneiss. It is estimated to be 1.8 billion years old! It is distinguished by its striking light and dark stripes and is noticeably different than the lighter-colored monzogranite cliffs and boulders below.  

In addition to the views and interesting geology, Ryan Mountain is habitat for some of the park’s elusive wildlife – the Desert bighorn sheep. Keep an eye out for these magnificent animals during your ascent and descent.  

Due to its popularity, visitors should arrive early to secure a parking spot on busy days. Pack warm layers on cold and windy days, and always bring adequate food and water supplies and sun protection. This hike is not recommended in the summer due to extreme heat.
audioDescription: The Ryan Mountain Trailhead is located in a large flat valley with rocky mountains in every direction. Around the parking area and trailhead there are several rock formations as well as scattered Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs. The parking area is a paved half loop connecting to Park Boulevard on either side with regular parking spots on the south side and RV spots on the north side. A dirt trail heads south from the center of the parking lot towards Ryan Mountain. There is a pit toilet on the north side of the parking lot.

title: Ryan Ranch Trailhead
listingDescription: Trailhead for hiking to Ryan Ranch

images.altText: A historic adobe type structure with boulders and a mountain in the background.
images.title: Ryan Ranch

bodyText:
Ryan Ranch is a one-mile (round trip) out-and-back hike with a 135-foot elevation gain. The trail travels along an old ranch road to a historic adobe structure at the base of Ryan Mountain. Ryan Ranch was built as a homestead in 1896 by J.D. Ryan, who operated the Lost Horse Mine. There are also remnants of past at the site such as a fallen windmill and old building materials. Do not remove any artifacts from the site. 

The Ryan Ranch Trail is a great place to discovery the park’s history while enjoying views of Ryan Mountain. This trail is typically less crowded than those close by and can offer peaceful solitude. 

You can access this trail from the parking area along Park Boulevard or from Ryan Campground near site 14.
audioDescription: Ryan Ranch Trailhead is in a desert valley bottom with rocky mountains in a every direction. A dirt trail heads south from a small parking area on the south side of Park Boulevard. The area is filled with scattered Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs.

title: San Gorgonio View

images.altText: A landscape of desert plants with a snowcapped mountain in the background.
images.title: San Gorgonio View

bodyText: From this vantage point, on all but the foggiest days, the peak of Mount San Gorgonio is visible, rising from the San Bernardino Mountains and topping out at 11,503 feet above sea level. These mountains are the reason why this area is a desert. Moist air from the Pacific Ocean is pushed east by wind  towards Joshua Tree National Park, but the mountains are too large an obstacle for wet, heavy clouds, so most of the moisture is discharged before the clouds can make their way over to Joshua Tree. Precipitation on the west (ocean) side of the mountains can be more than double the precipitation on the eastern side.
audioDescription: This stop is along a dirt path through desert mountains with ridges on either side. The area is filled with a mix of scattered Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs. In the distance to the west, the San Bernardino Mountains rise up along the distant horizon.

title: Short Loop Trailhead
listingDescription: Trailhead for the Short Loop Trail.

images.altText: A trailhead sign with a map and photo stands next to a dirt path that two visitors are walking on.
images.title: Black Rock Backpacking Board

bodyText:
This 4-mile loop hike passes through the hills, washes, ravines, and valleys east of the Black Rock Campground. It is a great hike for those camping in Black Rock or those looking to explore the quieter side of the park. 

Enjoy the scattered Joshua trees, Juniper trees, rabbitbrush, and the occasional pinyon pine. Keep an eye out for jackrabbits, lizards, and the rarely seen desert tortoise.  

Because this trail is located at a higher elevation than much of the park, it has slightly cooler temperatures on warm days. However, there is very little shade mid-day, so it is not recommended in the summer heat. Make sure to bring at least 2 liters of water and proper sun protection.  

 

There are multiple options for parking. Park at the Black Rock Backcountry Trailhead or park at the Black Rock Nature Center and start the trail near campsite 30. On busy days, there is additional overflow parking in the horse camp area.
audioDescription: A large sign with a small roof reads "Black Rock Canyon" and has a map of the area. Next to it is a "No Pets on Trail" sign. A dirt path leads away from the trailhead. Joshua trees, juniper bushes, yuccas, and other desert shrubs cover the landscape. Hills are visible in the distance.

title: Skull Rock
listingDescription: Skull Rock is one the most unique and popular rock formations in Joshua Tree National Park.

images.altText: A large rock with two holes resembling eye sockets sticking out of a rock and boulder field.
images.title: Skull Rock
images.caption: Skull Rock

bodyText: Skull Rock is a popular destination along Park Boulevard just east of Jumbo Rocks Campground. Formed over many millennia, water drops have slowly eroded two large holes into the rock to make the rock resemble a skull. Skull Rock can be reached by the Skull Rock Nature Trail just a short walk from the parking area.
audioDescription: Skull Rock is a tall granite rock with two large holes in its front resembling eye sockets. Skull Rock is located within an area filled with large rock formations and boulders with scattered small trees and shrubs between the rocks. A dirt path winds its way through the rocks to reach Skull Rock.

title: Skull Rock and Discovery Trail Trailheads
listingDescription: Trailheads for the Skull Rock Nature Trail and Discovery Trail.

images.altText: Scattered shrubs and a skull rock sign pointing towards large rock formations in the background.
images.title: Skull Rock Area
images.caption: The Skull Rock Trailhead

bodyText: Located along Park Boulevard between Jumbo Rocks and Live Oak, these trailheads provide access to the Skull Rock Nature Trail and the Discovery Trail. The Skull Rock Nature Trail is a 1.7 mile loop that can be started from trailheads on either side of the road. The north side of the loop also provides access to the Discovery Trail. Both trails are dirt and rock, include stairs and steep sections, and have narrow locations.
audioDescription: Located along a paved road are two dirt trails heading off from either side with a crosswalk in between. There are paved parking spots on each side of the road. There are large rock formations on both sides of the road surrounded by scattered Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs.

title: Sky’s the Limit
listingDescription: An observatory and park partner that offers astronomy programs.

images.altText: A 15 foot observatory with a paved path in front of clouds lit by sunset over mountains.
images.title: Sky's the Limit
images.caption: Sky's the Limit

bodyText: Sky’s the Limit is one of Joshua Tree National Park's non-profit partners. Located outside of the park between the north entrance and the town of Twentynine Palms, Sky's the Limit provides educational programs on astronomy and the night sky. Sky’s the Limit includes an observatory, welcome center, nature trail, orrery, and meditation garden. For current info and events visit their website.
audioDescription: Sky's the Limit is located in a wide desert valley with mountains in the distance. There is a large parking area that ends in a loop around an orrery made up of a circles of stones representing the solar system. As you first enter the parking lot there is a small welcome center to the right. Past the welcome center is a short nature trail that connects back to the main parking area. At the main parking area there is a 15 foot observatory housing a 14 inch telescope and pit toilets connected by a paved path. Beyond the observatory, a dirt path leads to a meditation garden.

title: Split Rock Trailhead
listingDescription: Split Rock picnic area and trailhead.

images.altText: A picnic table in front of small shrubs and a rock formation.
images.title: Split Rock Picnic Area
images.caption: Split Rock Picnic Area

bodyText:
Split Rock Loop Trail is a 2.5-mile loop hike with 150 feet of elevation gain. On the trail, you’ll see scenic views of the unique rock formations, the jumbo rocks area, and wide-open desert landscapes. You'll also have a chance to take a short spur trail to see Face Rock. 

The trail's namesake, Split Rock, is located at the trailhead and is easy to view. If you're looking for a scenic spot to have lunch, there is picnic tables near the trailhead. 

Some parts of the trail may be challenging to follow as they intersect with washes and social trails. Pay attention to the trail markers and use the app's offline map option to stay on the trail. Since there is little to no shade, hiking during the summer heat is not recommended. Make sure to bring enough food and water supplies and proper sun protection.
audioDescription: Split Rock is nestled among rock formations. This is a rocky area with scattered shrubs with a trailhead for a dirt and rocky trail, picnic tables, and a dirt parking area. Picnic tables are close to the parking lot and to the east, north, and northwest of the lot.

title: Star Wars Rock Viewpoint and Climbing Access Trailhead

images.altText: A dirt road leads towards rocks, a desert valley, and mountains.
images.title: Star Wars Rock Pullout
images.caption: The view from the Star Wars Rock pullout.

bodyText:
Building Boulders  

The unique, sculpted granitic boulder piles seen throughout the park are the result of jointing, weathering, and erosion. 

  1. Magma cooled and solidified miles beneath the surface to form various types of granitic rocks including the monzogranite that is common in the park. 

  1. Cracks or fractures— called joints— formed while these rocks were still underground due to stress from geologic forces. 

  1. Groundwater entered the joints and began rounding out the edges and corner, and weathering the rock into smaller pieces. 

  1. Erosion carried away small particles of broken-down rock, exposing rounded boulders. 

Notches mark the height and give us insight into past soil levels. The notches form because water in the soils is slightly acidic, slowly dissolving the rock away. Tafoni are concave pits of varying size that form on the rock’s surface from wind erosion or from soil contact (similar to how notches form). 

Exploration Area 

Scramble among the roadside boulders. See their crystalline structure. Feel their surfaces. Discover unique contours. 

Glossary 

Magma: Pressure and heat below the earth’s surface melts rock into a molten or semi-molten fluid called magma. When magma cools, igneous rocks are formed.  

Erosion: A geological process in which natural forces such as wind or water move natural materials like rocks, dirt, and sand.  

Weathering: natural process when water, wind, heat, plants and other forces, slowly break or change the rock. 

Monzogranite: a specific kind of biotite-rich granite rock. The monzogranite here is light-colored and is commonly seen in the northern part of Joshua Tree National Park.  

Tafoni: Rhymes with macaroni. Tafoni is a natural process that results in the formation of rock cavities. Tafoni occurs when long exposure to moisture eats away at a rock face. Stop by Skull Rock and look at the eye sockets and nose to see large examples of tafoni.
audioDescription: A small dirt pullout along Geology Tour Road. To the west are light-colored, granitic rock piles, including one called Star Wars Rock. Desert vegetation surrounds the area. The pullout is small and can only fit a few vehicles.

title: Start Here (Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center)
listingDescription: Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center in Twentynine Palms, California

images.altText: A large brown and black building with an NPS arrowhead. A flagpole stands next to the parking lot.
images.title: Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center
images.caption: Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center

bodyText: The Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center is located in downtown Twentynine Palms and features educational exhibits, a bookstore and giftshop, and visitor information.
audioDescription: The Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center is located south of highway 62, by about half a block on Freedom Way. The building is surrounded by parking spaces and walkways on all sides. The visitor center is in the middle of the town of Twentynine Palms. There are other buildings in sight as well as sparse desert vegetation. To the south the mountains in the north boundary of Joshua Tree National Park can be seen. The visitor center itself is a dark tan, single-story building. There is a flag pole and shade structure near the front of the building facing highway 62. The parking spaces on the northside of the building are the closest to the front door and there are a few handicap parking spaces. There is a sidewalk surrounding the building.

title: Start Here (Joshua Tree Sign)
listingDescription: The Joshua Tree National Park entrance sign at the south end of the park.

images.altText: A brick sign reads "Entering Joshua Tree National Park" in front of a desert landscape.
images.title: Joshua Tree Entrance Sign (South)

bodyText: As you approach the park from the south, this welcome sign marks the park boundary. Take a moment to admire the Colorado Desert and the surrounding mountains. A short drive north from the sign is the Bajada Nature Trail. Continuing north, you'll come across the Cottonwood Visitor Center, campground, and other amenities.
audioDescription: A road made of pavement runs from north to south and connects the park to the interstate. Both the east and west sides of Cottonwood Spring Road have a paved pullout located on them. The landscape along the road is an open desert, which meets the edge of rocky mountains. The landscape features shrubs, Mojave Yuccas, Ocotillos, and small trees. During the spring season, wildflowers may be visible across the landscape. At the northern edge of the eastern pullout is a beige brick wall with a brown arrowhead that reads “National Park Service” and “Department of the Interior." On this sign is a large green tree, white mountain shape, and green bison painted at the bottom. To the left of the arrowhead is a large wooden sign with white paint that reads “Entering Joshua Tree National Park, United States Department of the Interior, National Park Service.”

title: Start Here (Joshua Tree Visitor Center)
listingDescription: The Joshua Tree Visitor Center located in Joshua Tree, California.

images.altText: A large gray building with brown shade structures. In front is a large metal art piece and cacti.
images.title: Joshua Tree Visitor Center
images.caption: Joshua Tree Visitor Center

bodyText: Located in downtown Joshua Tree just five miles from the West Entrance, the Joshua Tree Visitor Center offers educational exhibits, a bookstore, and visitor resources. Grab a park map, buy an entrance pass, and chat with a park ranger to get all your questions answered before heading into the park!
audioDescription: Joshua Tree Visitor Center is located outside the park in the village of Joshua Tree, population 8,000. It is five miles north of the West Entrance on Park Boulevard close to where Park Boulevard and Highway 62 intersect. From the intersection, heading south on Park Boulevard, the visitor center is on the right. The gravel parking lot, just south of the visitor center, can comfortably fit 40 cars. There is a curved cinder block wall that divides the parking lot from the visitor center. From the parking lot, there is a cement sidewalk leading a short distance through a modest cactus garden and ends at a small cement courtyard in front of the visitor center on the east side of the building. In the garden stands a flagpole and a rusted metal sculpture. The exterior of the single-story visitor center has walls that resemble corrugated metal. From the courtyard, another short cement sidewalk leads through a large wooden gate into an outdoor patio between the cinder block wall and the south side of the building. The patio is enclosed on its south end by the previously mentioned cinder block wall. Inside the patio, the ground is dirt and slopes down from the cinder block wall towards the double glass doors that lead into the visitor center. Two tables are on the patio near the doors where rangers can help visitors with information. Once entering the building, there is a one-room exhibit area with panels depicting geology, ecology, and history of Joshua Tree National Park. There is a life-sized replica of a Joshua tree accompanied with panels about the Joshua tree. There is a guitar and a U2 record album on display that represents the creative aspects of Joshua Tree National Park. There is a television that plays a 2-minute video about the park’s geology. The exhibit opens into the one-room bookstore. On display are souvenirs—stickers, patches, t-shirts, hats, stuffed animals, mugs, postcards, and books. On the side of the bookstore closest to the exhibit is a counter with three cash registers. Opposite the counter, on the north side, are two doors that open directly into the men’s and women’s bathrooms. Exit through the bookstore's double glass doors back to the courtyard on the east side of the visitor center. The northernmost section of the building, with a single glass door that opens out into the courtyard, is a cafe.

title: Stubbe Springs Trailhead

images.altText: A trailhead sign reads" Juniper Flats" in a landscape of scattered Joshua trees and desert shrubs.
images.title: Juniper Flats Backpacking Board

bodyText:
Stubbe Springs is a 12-mile “lollipop” loop hike in the Juniper Flats area. This trail is great for hikers looking for a long loop hike and solitude in the backcountry. It begins in an open valley filled with grasses, desert shrubs, and Joshua trees. The trail then passes through scenic high points, canyons, and mountainous terrain with Pinyon pines and juniper. 

On the loop section, you will discover Stubbe Springs, a natural water source with thick vegetation surrounding it. You will also have the option to extend your hike on a short spur trail to the Fan Canyon Overlook and see stunning views of the Coachella Valley.  

 

If backpacking or backcountry camping in this area, permits are required. Camping is not allowed near Stubbe Spring due to the sensitive resources.
audioDescription: There is a dirt parking lot behind a fence post. A roofed backcountry trailhead reads "Juniper Flats" and provides information about the surrounding area. The dirt path leads away from the trailhead into a landscape with desert shrubs, grasses, and many Joshua trees. There are rocky mountains in the distance.

title: That’s Gneiss
listingDescription: Stop one for the Hi-View Nature Trail Tour.

images.altText: A large boulder with black, white, and brown colors surrounded by desert shrubs.
images.title: That's Gneiss

bodyText: Black Rock Canyon gets its name from the main color in this metamorphic rock. It is called Pinto Gneiss (pronounced “nice) and is estimated to be more than 1.8 billion years old. Look closely to observe intricate banding and mineral crystals in the rock. Exposed rock is excellent habitat for lichens, several species of which can be observed on this outcropping. Look for bright splotches of green, orange, and yellow growing on the rocks. Different species can be identified by color and shape.
audioDescription: A dirt trail heading up between two ridges. The area is filled with scattered rocks, Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs. On the left side of the trail a large rock made of Pinto Gneiss sticks up out of the ground.

title: The Towers of Uncertainty Viewpoint and Rock Climbing Access Trailhead

images.altText: Rock formations on the horizon
images.title: Towers of Uncertainty
images.caption: Viewpoint of the Towers of Uncertainty Rock Formations

bodyText:
An Island Getaway 

The large boulder piles of light-colored rocks that pop up from the flat plains are inselbergs, meaning “island hill” in German; they speckle the landscape like islands speckle an ocean. Inselbergs are the core of ancient hills, and they are revealed when the soil above them weathers and erodes away. The inselbergs remain while the other substances erode away around them because they are stronger and more durable. 

The Island Life 

Humans: Strong, durable rock in Joshua Tree attracts rock climbers. The rocks around you have hundreds of climbing routes. Climbers from all over the world come to Joshua Tree to climb these inselbergs. 

Raptors: Predatory birds perch and nest near the high peaks of these rocks. From the pinnacles, raptors can search for prey running through the valley floors all around. This area is often closed to climbing in the spring and summer to protect the park’s nesting raptors. Climbers should check climbing closures on the park website before climbing.  

Vegetation: Water is a valuable commodity in the desert. When rain lands on inselbergs, it runs off to areas at the base of the rock adding additional moisture to the soil. The inselberg also shields some of the soil at its base from the sun, especially on the north side. The addition of water and shade in the desert creates unique microclimates that allow certain plant species to thrive.  

Glossary 

Inselberg: Isolated terrain that abruptly rises above the surrounding area. Inselbergs can be rock formations, hills, ridges, or small mountains.  

Erosion: A geological process in which natural forces such as wind or water move natural materials like rocks, dirt, and sand. 

Microclimate: The climate of a small, specific area that differs from the climate of the surrounding area. 

Weathering: A natural process when water, wind, heat, plants and other forces, slowly break or change the rock.
audioDescription: A very small, dirt pullout on the side of the road has space for 2–3 vehicles. To the west of this pullout are tall, light-colored, granitic rock formations. The rest of the surrounding area is scattered with desert vegetation. The pullout is on the westside of Geology Tour Road.

title: Topography and Faults(Keys View)
listingDescription: Learn about topography at Keys View on the JTNP Audio Tour

images.altText: Dry rocky mountains with a small tree leading to a valley in the distance under puffy clouds.
images.title: Keys View
images.caption: Keys View looking across the Little San Bernardino Mountains into the Coachella Valley.

bodyText:
Keys View provides wide panoromic views of the southern side of Joshua Tree National Park. Perched in the Little San Bernardino Mountains, Keys View offers exceptional views of the mountains as they flow into the Coachella Valley below. On a very clear day, it is even possible to see Signal Mountain in Mexico 90 miles to the south.

From the parking area you can enjoy the .25 mile paved Keys View Nature Trail for more views as well as educational wayside signs along the trail.
audioDescription: As you enter Keys View there is a large paved loop parking area with a paved sidewalk and stone wall along the overlook. From the overlook there are wide views of the Little San Bernardino Mountains with Coachella Valley in the distance and a second mountain range on the horizon. The mountains are rugged and rocky with scattered small trees and shrubs. To the left of the overlook, a paved trail leads to more views.

title: Tortoise Crossing

images.altText: A dirt path through rocks and small shrubs.
images.title: Tortoise Crossing

bodyText: The trail seems steep for short reptilian legs, but desert tortoises (Gopherus agassizii) are impressively stalwart creatures that travel through the desert scrub to cross passes like this one in search of wildflowers to eat. In the spring, visitors sometimes spot tortoises while hiking on the High View Nature Trail, so keep an eye out! Tortoises are a federally threatened species; if you are lucky enough to see one be sure to give it plenty of space. Report any tortoise observations at the Black Rock Nature Center as scientists are eager for information on these elusive animals.
audioDescription: This stop is located on a dirt path along ridge in desert mountains. The area contains Joshua trees, scattered trees, and shrubs.
